Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is a retro tower defense game. It is small in file size, but big in play! I like that I can easily run it in the background while I do other things on the computer.The story progresses nicely. The characters are engaging, and I was never bored with the plot. You can complete the entire plot in a day even if you take your time. The graphics are in pixel style for the gameplay. The cut-scenes were artwork with text underneath. The art would move in response to the text moving, like reading an illustrated book. This game has nice replay value. Every site on the map has 3 levels, easy, normal, and advanced. To unlock everything, you must beat all three. There are a lot of achievements in this game, and some of them are quite difficult to get. A single level can be solved in many different ways. And, the whole game can be played in newgame+ mode, which makes beating it a second time a new challenge.Once I finished the plot, I found that I don't like to play for hours on end. The game is relaxing for me. I take my time with the higher level achievements. It's a fun, simple game and I recommend it.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												Short: [9/10] Awesome and challenging Tower Defense x RPG mix with 30+ hours of gameplay. Only a few gripes make this game short of perfect.Long: "Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten" is a Tower Defense game in which you fight hordes of enemies by using different classes and spells. The classes (of which there are 6) all differ in playstyle and give the game its RPG elements via XP gains, talent trees and weapon/armor aquisition. Even though the game looks simple, it offers a very deep combat and leveling system which will have to be adjusted multiple times in order to beat certain levels. Examples include making your archers target fastest enemies first, putting the stun sword in the hands of your knight, or making sure your ice skills don't get cancelled by your burn ones.  The story itself is amusing as well and gave me a few chuckles along the way. New Game+, 3 star rating per level, and challenges such as endless mode only extend the life of this game and make you want to play more. There are however, a few issues. Some, like the "Undo" button, which removes ALL the points you just put into your character's skill tree instead of just the last one, should be renamed "Restart" because that's what it actually does. This gets very annoying when respeccing a character with 60 points in New Game+. However, the "Undo" button is not game breaking so it doesn't change my rating of the game. What does, however, is the terrible frame drop encountered during big fights. Even though I have a very powerful rig, it has caused the game to crash several times (once while on 95th wave of endless when attempting 100 wave achievement!). Another is the poor visual of the cursor, which when coupled with the fact the frame rates drop, makes it impossible to see. This has caused me to lose a few games or constantly pause to execute commands.But the few imperfections get dwarfed by the fact this is a great game, and had me coming back for that "JUST ONE MORE ROUND" feel. The devs are actually pretty cool/active as well and respond quite frequently in the forums. Don't miss this game, it is very much worth it!   [9/10]

												Defender's Quest is a tower defense style game with RPG-based elements added in.  I liked it; overall, it's a quaint little game. Posted: April 2
												Defender's Quest is an excellent tower defense game that, while not perfect, is one of the better offerings in the genre.The pros (+) and cons (-) are as follows:+ Solid tower defense gameplay. It follows a typical X unit is good against X enemy type formula, and for the most part this works well.+ The story in this game is much better than you'd ever expect from a game of this type. You can more-or-less ignore it if you don't care, but if you take the time to read the journal entries, you'll find that the world and characters are very fleshed out. A lot of the characters and situations are very tongue-in-cheek, which relieves some of the tension a game like this can inspire. :)+ Level design constantly pushes  you out of your comfort zone. You often find that you can't quite use units in the way that you'd want to because of the limitations on the terrain. Things don't get as monotonous as a result of this.+ For a tower defense game, it's pretty long. If you're a veteran of the genre and can breeze through tough fights with effortless tactical accumen, you'll find that getting maximum stars on each level takes about 10-15+ hours.+ New Game Plus (NG+) adds sidequests that aren't available in the normal game, which includes new story and cutscenes. The behind-the-scenes journal entries are also really interesting.+ Hero Mode makes for an even more challenging game (you can only use the 6 story characters).+ Lots of customization for loadouts, units, etc. Branching skill trees make the customization feel a little more fleshed out, although some options are clearly better than others.+ The DX version of the game vastly improves the graphics. The biggest mark against the original game was that it was in SD and the art looked very amateur. With this update, the game supports HD/Widescreen resolutions, and all sprites/cutscenes look 1000% better.+ You have the option of increasing the amount of XP and Scrap (money) you get after each battle by up to 300%. Scrap isn't all that useful, but XP is mana from heaven. This is great, because if you left it at 100%, it'd take a metric ♥♥♥♥ton of grinding to get to the end of the game. See cons for reasons why even this feature doesn't save NG+ from grindiness, unfortunately.- In the normal game, Rangers are by far the best unit. You can win almost every fight by just using them, even on Expert. It seems that the developers were very aware of this, which is why --- In NG+, the Ranger (the only real ranged unit in the game) is the subject of immense nerfs. Many enemies that appear in large numbers and have high speed either have 50% resistance to ranged damage, or 60-70% ranged evasion. These are the kinds of enemies you'd want an archer for because they can slip past your melee, but your archers can't hit them. This really hurts the unit's viability in a lot of fights. I feel like the challenge could have been increased without this frustrating change. There are some enemies that the Ranger is still really good at dealing with, but mostly you'll be relying on melee in Expert modes.- Most of the added difficulty in NG+ is artificial. Inflated HP and stats, enemies that phase out so that you can't target them, etc. You're often forced to spam global spells to deal with certain situations because your units simply can't no matter how you have them set up. This mode just isn't very well done in my opinion. It's frustrating and tedious, not fun.- The super sheep levels are tedious and not fun at all. You kill a slow moving sheep (that you can slow even more) that has about a bazillion HP and takes optimal tactics and resource management to kill before it reaches the end of the level. It is a very boring, very long fight even with the game sped up to 16x speed, and you have to do it TWICE in order to get all the achievements. If you're a completionist, you'll be subjected to several grindy annoyances, which brings me to the final gripe:- If you complete the game in Hero Mode (can't recruit units), once you've finished those achievements (after finishing NG+), you'll want to recruit units because there are some levels that are impossible to get 3 gold stars on with only the main 6 heroes. Unfortunately, the recruited units at that point will be so low level that even setting the XP to 300% is an unbearable grind to get them to 60. Battles take a long time to fight, and the XP from a battle -might- give your units half a level. You can imagine how long this would take. This was originally a community challenge that the developers put into the game later (along with associated achievements), but they didn't really balance the post-achievement gameplay for it. I actually gave up with only a few achievements left to get. Not worth it.Overall, if you're interested in a tower defense game that's challenging and satisfying in the base game, and aren't too concerned with unlocking every last achievement, then this game is for you. If you love punishing grinds, NG+ has you covered.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												An extremely user-friendly interface, charming graphics, a solid base gameplay (with lots of variations and different levels of challenge) and entertaining, even if not mindblowing, story and dialogue.The base game doesn't last very long, but that also means that it doesn't overstay its welcome and that each level has at least a little something that makes it unique and prevents the player from always using the same strategy. The fact that each level has two optional challenges and that there's a New Game+ mean that there are a lot of potential challenges for the players who want them.Most importantly, the user interface never hides any information. You always know exactly what your characters can do and what the enemies will do if you let them. If you lose in this game it's because you did something wrong or your characters weren't strong enough, not because of some obscure "gotcha" mechanic or random chance.My only problem with the game is the fact that interesting and important story content (a personal sidequest for each one of the major characters) is only available in New Game + mode. When you're replaying the game, you're probably fast-forwarding past the story so you're probably going to see these scenes in a vacuum. On the other hand when you're playing the first time, which is the only time you're actually paying attention to the story, the characters will feel underdeveloped because their development is hidden in their personal sidequests. I think the game would be better if all story content were available during your first "run", and the New Game+ mode was just about gameplay and challenge.That said, this is an interesting and charming little game that succeeds in fusing RPG progression and tower defense gameplay, and is more than worth the money.

												This is a game where battles take place in a tower defense style, but you progress by roaming around a map while fighting these battles. Has elements of the old Shining Force / Disgaea games where: 1. Characters gain levels and advance2. Strategic placement of characters during the battle is important3. You can go back and replay old battles for more experience You select the difficulty of each battle before you run it. Doing old battles at higher difficulties yeilds higher rewards. The game is progressive without feeling too grind-ish.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Defender's Quest combines the classic tower defense formula with RPG elements in a way that feels both classic and fresh at the same time. Because it works within the established TD formula, it's familiar and accessible. Because it replaces towers with hired heroes who level up, learn new active and passive skills, and equip new gear, it's offbeat and original. The art is both childlike and gritty. The story, the game's weakest point, is still functional and effective, and the simple characters are fun and relatable. It's a little short, but there's replay value both in beating older missions on higher difficulties and in starting a new adventure with new hero builds. Overall, a charming and unique hybrid of the Tower Defense and RPG genres.

Posted: May 14, 2014
												I got this game as part of a humble bundle and immediatly saw that it is a tower defence game, which deterred me a little, however, as it is a small game to download, I figured I'd give it a try.Thus far I have enjoyed the game for a number of reasons;The first being that the characters all have interesting personalities.The next being that the cutscenes are humorous, with jokes that are reminiscent of Dragonfable, but still fresh.Finally, you have a fairly large number of strategic choices with how you set your units, and which ones you power up.I would recommend this game, especially if you are looking for a tower defence game which can be run on low-end computers, or if you simply enjoy the tower defence genre.

Posted: September 22, 2016
												Great tower defence game with many customization options to suit your gameplay!You can modify game elements before you start the game such as :.exp modifier x1-3 exp gain. currency modifier x1-3 gain.This allows you to play the way you preferr.The game also has a variety of speed modifiers allowing you to slow down or pause your gameplay in order to make tactical decisions in the heat of battle.The story is nothing grand but very comical and wll have you laughing throughout.Character skills are customizeable and the game has suprisingly in depth skills customization options.All in all this game is well worth the money if your into tower defence games!

Posted: November 25, 2016
												 Really great spin on a TD where your towers are your hero party and level up as you go. This means your limited by the size of your party to how many towers you can place in each level. This limitation is good and really hones the sort of strategy this game is about. Each map is well designed and offers a different challenge.    Each party member (tower) has their different effects/weaknesses/skills. They can be equipped with items and weapons for different effects emphasising the RPG elements. Placement and arrangement is super important, just like any other TD.  The game is immensely replayable, and has a superb difficulty settings options to mould the game to exact sort of challenge you want. All the way from absurdly easy to absurdly hard.  The game offers a great challenge for completionists.  The soundtrack is awesome and has a hint of 90's JRPG soundtracks within it. Probably the best blind purchase I've made on steam.  Worth it at full price.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is one of those rare RPG / tower defense games that are actually really good. The story was pretty good. The gameplay was pretty balanced. It's only as difficult as you want it to be which is perfect. The graphics are... well, look at the screenshots. I completed the story, and I'm not bored with it yet. Which is good because the game unlocked an entirely new game mode which means many more hours of playtime. The game has a bunch of well placed humor which adds a lot to the game / story. The game was definitely worth what I paid for it, and I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a game like this.For the record, I played in Hero only mode which added some challenge while also making the micro-managing a lot easier. I found out that the default 300% scrap setting is way too high since I never spend any of it... except for the last stretch where the stores give you access to a lot of really expensive gear which pretty much consumed most of my scrap.I especially laughed when the game decided to reward me anyways for my stubborness.

Posted: November 18, 2012
												Edit again: Okay, now I can change my review back to a recommended. While the rerelease had a really shaky start, the devs have been great about talking to people, filing bug reports, and a really quickly released series of patches that have put the game in a good state again. I'm glad that the game is stable again because it remains one of my favorites and most played in my entire Steam library.Edit: Three and a half years later, I'm having to edit my review on the HD rerelease of the game. Do no buy it in its current condition. It is an incredibly buggy mess. The game constantly crashes, graphical and UI glitches abound, certain equipped items will make maps literally unwinnable. How this version of the game was allowed to see the light of day is baffling. Wait until it's been patched a few times, which the devs ARE being very quick and responsive about.If you at all enjoy tower defense games, buy this. Now. It injects cocaine through your mouse and keyboard right into your body. It's so addictive it's ridiculous. Posted: July 9, 2016
												Update: I am changing my vote to "recommend this game".I have accepted Fox's suggestion and set XP+scrap gain to 300%. Now the game is FUN instead of being frustrating. And it is still challenging, the "extreme" difficulty requires some skill (and a little grinding). I think that this should have been the default setting for this game.Now I also enjoy the side quests in the "new game+" mode.Bottom line : recommended !Just for the record, this was my previous review:I am somewhat disappointed from this game. I really wanted to like it - it has a genuine idea (combination of tower defense + RPG) , it is not expensive (on sales often) and the developers seem to care about the customers. Also I have to admit that the cut scenes are funny.However, it is simply a grinding game. Some levels are just too difficult, no matter how clever and resourceful you are. You have to go back and play earlier levels, until you grind enough XP and money to buy a better equipment. Then the level becomes easy, and you win it no matter what tactics you use. In other words, the game rewards you not for your talent, but for the time you spend playing it.In addition, the graphics and sound are just like from the 80's. Perhaps this is the designers' intention, but I didn't like it.I would recommend this game only if you are a tower defense fanatic and only when it is on sale.

												Fun Tower Defense game where your towers are RPG characters that you can equip with gear and upgrade the skills of.The levels in the story line have multiple difficulty levels, which throw increasingly more high level monsters at you. Posted: July 5, 2016
												Defenders Quest is a well-balanced Tower Defense game that replaces static towers with RPG-element-laden characters. With six classes, skill trees and weapons and armor there's plenty of customization to be had.It is a little repetative, as the game expects you to run certain levels over a few times to gather much needed XP and money, but it doesn't overstay its welcome. It's got a story with characters I cared about, which is a hard thing to do for a TD game, and it ended before things started getting stale. A well-rounded experience! :)I would sing this game's praises in the same breath as Kingdom Rush. A gold standard to the genre.

Posted: February 27, 2016
												At its core, Defender's Quest is a tower defense game in which your towers aren't just expendable resources that don't change from level to level.  In Defender's Quest, your towers are customizable heroes, with skill trees and a wide variety of abilities.  The story, art style, and music are all rather presentable, and even charming at times, and the core mechanic of leveling up your troops and acquiring new gear has tremendous Pavlovian allure.  It's a fairly expensive game for its relative simplicity, but it nonetheless hugely entertaining.  At full price or on sale, I can't help but recommend Defender's Quest.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												A competent and enjoyable, if somewhat limited, tower-defense gameMost of the challenge comes from the mixture of enemies in each wave and the limited ability to create the prototypical "kill zones". Enemy times have specific vulnerabilities, and some of the player's defense units are direct counters for these vulnerabilities. Usually, a mixture of units in each lane, with an emphasis on archers, will suffice for most challenges.It's not a super-difficult or revolutionary game by any means. Its production values are very limited, and that will bother some. But it has a lot of humor, a competent save-the-world storyline, and some interesting units (dragons, for instance, are hard to use well).I'd recommend this game for someone looking for a little dash of charm with their casual, traditional tower-defense experience.

Save the world. It has a respectable quantity of levels, and if you really get into it, you can play a large variety of challenge levels, as well as play through the games levels on higher difficulties, or in New Game + for additional enemy abilities and strength.The art was a great aesthetic for a TD, the difficulty curve was flexible and fun, and the music was pretty ok. Definitely worth picking up on it's next sale.

Posted: January 16, 2015
												10/10I did not knew that DQ will become one of my favorite games of all time. I spotted a game on sale on Steam. Checked the screens, description, some players opinions. Mix of Tower Defense and RPG? That sounded interesting. It turned out that it was a game I was waiting for.Graphics are really good. They're tidy, have charm. Well, ok cut-scenes could look better, but they're not bad. Still visuals are not important here.What is important is gameplay. What can I say, it's brilliant. You're placing heroes, of few classes, on battle field, changing tactic with each new level. Characters varies, have nice skills, synergize well. With each battle they gain experience points which leads to new levels and skill points, making your heroes stronger. It adds a little grind to classic Tower Defense game. You can revisit once done levels, increasing it's difficulty to gain bonuses. And then, after the game is over, there is new game plus, making things even more complicated.You will have Dragon in your team and you will kill sheeps!Story starts suddenly, with our protagonist Azra, just like us, surprised with events that occurs. With time we will learn about plague and revenants, will find out who is the villain. It's nothing ground-breaking but is good excuse to continue the adventure. There is even a moral decision!The key part is the dialogues. They're simply amazing. Heroes are crazy so we ends up with many fun jokes, that will leave you with minutes of laugh. There are few misses, still author's sense of humor turns out to be very good. Good stuff.Defender's Quest is great game. Fantastic example of how well Tower Defense can work with RPG. This game gave me plenty of great time, it offers lots of content, making it one of my better purchases. I recommend it to everyone. You won't be dissapointed.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												This game may not have cutting-edge graphics, but it sure has a lot of heart.  Defender's Quest is a strange combination of the tower defense and RPG genres, and it's one of my very favorite games in either genre.  Through the game's substantial and satisfying campaign, you'll assemble a motley crew of heroes who serve as your "towers" in this tower defense game.  Unlike towers, however, your heroes will level up as they gain experience, and you can assign various skills and pieces of equipment to them.  It's fun stuff.The developers for this game are fantastic, and their continued work on Defender's Quest highlights their "long tail" philosophy.  Rather than abandoning their game after release, Level Up Labs have diligently improved upon their work, adding content, improving the graphics, and rebuilding the engine.  Defender's Quest is far more refined now than it was upon release, and its developers ought to be proud. Defender's Quest is an excellent game with a committed development team, and I very much look forward to its in-development sequel.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												Wow. This game really is good.I'm a bit more than halfway through as of writing this and I'm having a blast. The writing and humour is really quite good, and gameplay is nice. I find the characters really quite endearing indeed!So about the gameplay:If you've read the description, you'd know it's a tower-defense game with rpg elements; i.e. your "towers" are actually characters which level up permanently (though you still "upgrade"  them in battle). It's pretty brilliant; you can choose to grind to level them up to tackle harder levels, or you can try a no-grind approach to see if you can tough out the main missions.The gameplay is really quite smooth and although the mechanics are not anything different from other tower defense games, work really quite well.I grabbed it while it had 67% off and I feel it's well worth it, even at full price. Very well made, and I feel the creators really put their soul into this game.

												Bought this on a whim, wasn't expecting much, to be honest. But I do love tower defense, and it runs on linux, so I went ahead with the purchase. Very impressed, this game is actually very excellent and has an old-school SNES feel with modern tower defense. I've been playing it over more publicly accredited games (it actually has pulled me away from DOTA 2), so decided that a positive review would help out a bit because I feel very strongly about how this hidden gem wasted an entire Sunday for me, and I'm still not done beating it 100%. I rarely care about beating games 100%, I think the last time I did it was for a little-known title called Goldeneye in the 90's.Excellent concept: merges RPG with tower defense. That's all there is to say, really. Units seem to be all useful, but as with ANY old-school RPG combat it can get super easy or impossible depending on whether or not you grind. Regardless on that, there are technically four difficulties (if you count casual) that change each battle's difficulty hugely. Story is alright -- the humor isn't my cup of tea, but then again, I have a picture of the dude from The Human Centipede 2 as my steam picture, so I just gotta say it's a me thing.Looks like they're making a sequel. Good, I'll be sure to buy it.If you're on linux and can't figure out why the game doesn't start without an error message, you need Adobe AIR. Their website is quite good on showing you how to get it running. A minor setback, I'm sure with licensing reasons Steam can't install it as a dependency. However, it almost made me assume the game was poorly ported and bugged (like Dead Island which doesn't boot on linux for some and nobody knows why, LOL). The devs obviously cared a lot about this game: it's not junk meant to be sold to chumps where they buy it on sale, play for 15 minutes, then never open it up again. The writing is good -- not perfect, but meant to be (ugh) all ages. It's not a super deep story, though I feel with more practice they could pull it off if they feel it wouldn't detract from the gameplay in the sequel.I would advise the devs to look at their website and tone down on the humor -- had my bored, cynical♥♥♥♥♥seen it without playing the game I would've assumed this game would be♥♥♥♥♥♥ The art isn't AAA title, but as an indie game, what the ♥♥♥♥ do you expect? The battles are mid 90's SNES quality (though better than Breath of Fire II, worse than FF6) and the cutscenes are adobe flash-esque and very similar to the indie game Sequence (minus the voice acting, plus more character gestures).If the game was a teensy little longer and made for the SNES, with a little more "professionalism" mixed in, it would've been a classic everyone would've known about. I came in expecting♥♥♥♥♥♥and found a gem I hadn't heard about before. I'm old, drunk, and cranky, and this stole an entire day from me and perhaps longer. Def buy @ $10, even $15. It's about on par with binding of isaac.

Posted: February 27, 2016
												At its core, Defender's Quest is a tower defense game in which your towers aren't just expendable resources that don't change from level to level.  In Defender's Quest, your towers are customizable heroes, with skill trees and a wide variety of abilities.  The story, art style, and music are all rather presentable, and even charming at times, and the core mechanic of leveling up your troops and acquiring new gear has tremendous Pavlovian allure.  It's a fairly expensive game for its relative simplicity, but it nonetheless hugely entertaining.  At full price or on sale, I can't help but recommend Defender's Quest.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												I do recommend this game if you enjoy games of the tower defense or puzzle genre. I highly recommend you stay away from this game if you have never enjoyed the TD genre. This is a wonderful game. The game has a (what I refer to) pick your own challenge setting which basically consists of setting your own EXP and Scrap(Money) multiplier/%. It can be set up to 300% which is by far easy mode. The second playthrough is more fun than the first and it has great replayability in my opinion. Overall would give the game an 8/10 and I am happily looking forward to the second game.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												Played demo version long time ago I knew that I would fall in love with full version of Defender's Quest. Why is it so good? It have great replayability, which is in my opinion the most important thing in TD games. You can start to play on casuals and reach your way to the hardest settings. Even with few units you need to think how use them, how upgrade them, which one should get better stuff first etc. Maps and monsters are interesting. Same goes for story. While music and graphics are not so flashy, it fits really great for a game from Tower Defense genre. It inspire player to beat levels on hardest settings not only for achievements but also for stuff you can get from doing it. Also, there is one level with really annoying cute monster and it will demand from you a little knowledge on each unit skills and to come with a good strategy to beat it. There are also endless challenges so you can do your best over and over, beating your (and maybe your friends) wave scores. I'm glad I finally decided to play it. There are plenty of Tower Defense games on Steam but this one is greatly fun from start to the end. I will probably play it once again, when HD upgrade will be avaible. Also I won't hesitate to get second game shortly after release, since I enjoyed this one so much I have a really high expectation from next one.

												I got the game at offer and I am totally satisfied.The towers are actually fighters which you recuit and level up between fights.I played just 3 hours and I cannot say more yet but these 3 hours were fun :)...17 hours nowDialogs between characters are very funny :)I am trying to optimize my progress in such a way that I use as few "towers" as possible....23 hoursI played a map on higer difficulty to get an item and after I aquired the reward, instead of pressing equip button, I pressed continue. The item was not placed into the inventory. Just dissapeared. Luckily it was not an important item. This glitch could be very anoying....Finished the game. I guess the issue above might have been a missunderstanding from my side. The game filters the items - it shows only the ones the currently selected fighter can equip.

												Smartly written, it overshadows most tower defense titles with its emphasis on character growth and world-building. One can grow attached to Slack, for example, much more easily than one can grow attached to a nameless battlement or turret. The game provides a range of challenge suited to players of any skill level, with the new game + feature providing plenty of replay value. Highly recommended, even before the developers released a free upgrade.

Posted: June 17, 2016
												Got this game ages ago, liked it then, just finished playing it again when the fancy graphics came out, and it's even better now. The units and progression are pretty balanced (though I'd recommend playing with the XP and scrap at 300% or it gets grindy). Every unit is unique even within a type which adds an interesting bit of strategy. For instance I always give my best equipment to the story characters and boost them first in battles, so those characters have points in the high boost skills but my secondary fighters and archers have their points only in the low boost skills. There's a decent story with some funny dialog. Core story takes 10 to 15 hours to get through (with xp turned up), and there's quite a bit of replayability with the higher difficulties. I'm about to go start the new game+ myself. Oh, and there's a demo, so I'm not sure why you're reading reviews.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												Short: [9/10] Awesome and challenging Tower Defense x RPG mix with 30+ hours of gameplay. Only a few gripes make this game short of perfect.Long: "Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten" is a Tower Defense game in which you fight hordes of enemies by using different classes and spells. The classes (of which there are 6) all differ in playstyle and give the game its RPG elements via XP gains, talent trees and weapon/armor aquisition. Even though the game looks simple, it offers a very deep combat and leveling system which will have to be adjusted multiple times in order to beat certain levels. Examples include making your archers target fastest enemies first, putting the stun sword in the hands of your knight, or making sure your ice skills don't get cancelled by your burn ones.  The story itself is amusing as well and gave me a few chuckles along the way. New Game+, 3 star rating per level, and challenges such as endless mode only extend the life of this game and make you want to play more. There are however, a few issues. Some, like the "Undo" button, which removes ALL the points you just put into your character's skill tree instead of just the last one, should be renamed "Restart" because that's what it actually does. This gets very annoying when respeccing a character with 60 points in New Game+. However, the "Undo" button is not game breaking so it doesn't change my rating of the game. What does, however, is the terrible frame drop encountered during big fights. Even though I have a very powerful rig, it has caused the game to crash several times (once while on 95th wave of endless when attempting 100 wave achievement!). Another is the poor visual of the cursor, which when coupled with the fact the frame rates drop, makes it impossible to see. This has caused me to lose a few games or constantly pause to execute commands.But the few imperfections get dwarfed by the fact this is a great game, and had me coming back for that "JUST ONE MORE ROUND" feel. The devs are actually pretty cool/active as well and respond quite frequently in the forums. Don't miss this game, it is very much worth it!   [9/10]

Posted: June 17, 2016
												TL:DR : This game understands you. (8.75/10)The graphics aren't the best, but they're as good as they need to be; the soundtrack and effects are pleasant but not particularly obtrusive or overwhelming. The plot itself is as interesting as it needs to be, with dialogue amusing enough to read- but all of it can be readily skipped past or ignored as one pleases. In terms of gameplay, this is a solid tower defense/tactical RPG. LUL manages to skillfully blend the two, producing a well thought out, fairly original tower defense where one identifies with, develops, and equips one's 'towers' much as one would one's characters in games like FF Tactics or Bahamut's Lagoon. What is particularly striking about this game however, is not the gameplay itself- it's present in the gameplay, to be sure; but what really marks this game as interesting is the attention to detail the studio has given to ALL of the aspects. The graphics aren't the best, but they're every bit as good as they need to be. The plot and dialoge are easily skipped because this is a casual game, where you are not expected to care in the slightest, and yet they are still amusing and substantial enough for if you do happen to care for some reason. If you need solid proof that LUL clearly understands you, the gamer, just look at the attention they pay to the control scheme. You can play this game without a mouse. Easily. The mouse can help now and then, but these people have dialed in the control system of their game to such an extent that a skilled player could possibly even do better without a mouse than with one, and all the keys are fully mappable, in case their super-intuitive control scheme isn't super-intuitive enough. To be fair, I've noticed a glitch or two, but they always seem to get corrected fast enough that you would miss them if you blinked at the right moment.Overall, always good to see this level of attention being given at all levels of development. 8.75/10

Posted: October 18, 2014
												Defender's Quest (DQ) is a tower defense meets RPG hybrid. You go around with your ragtag bunch of misfit heroes, trying to save your skin and possibly the world. As you make your way, battle after battle, through hordes of zombies... I mean, Revenants, everyone's skills improve, making them harder, better, faster, stronger at slicing-and-dicing more undead meat.Is that all? No. DQ has a delicious old-school feel, partly thanks to the pixellated sprites, partly because of the great soundtrack which will make you think of the glorious days of SNES JRPGs. It also has some notably well-written dialogue, snappy and fun (though let's face it, the art in those scenes leaves something to be desired...). DQ also has lots of challenges for you. Playing levels at regular difficulty is getting too easy? No problem, you can replay them at Advanced or Extreme to get bonuses and goodies. Finished the game? No problem, there's a New Game+ with more difficulties awaiting for you. The learning curve is extremely well-balanced and I especially enjoyed being able to complete the main story without ever getting really stuck but with a very real sense of increased hardship towards the end (the last two-three battles, especially, I barely managed to power through).It's definitely a very good game, especially if you like tower defense. Get it.EDIT: the developers released a "DX" patch for this game adding new content, remaking the engine with HaxeFlixel and redrawing the art to be better - thus the only complaint I could ever muster about this game has now gone. This is nothing short of a masterpiece, and quite possibly the best tower defense game you'll find on Steam. Search no more.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												This is one of the few TDs that I can stand, mainly due to the cast of characters. In this  TD your towers are characters, that you will place on predefined maze, in order to stop the creeps from getting to Azra (the main character). The characters have persistent level ups (RPG), along side traditional tower level ups (TD), this makes that game a bit easier to manage when it comes to placing them on the battlefield. Characters automatically attack and chose which ability to attack with, unless otherwise told not to use an ability. Azra has several spells that can fight back against the oncoming hordes such as healing all placed characters and raining down fireballs to continuously burn enemies.In the game Azra has been tossed into the pit for contracting the plague, which she quickly overcomes to meet a loopy swordsman. The game manages to walk that fine line between seriousness and humor throughout the campaign. As you make your journey across the over-map you gained more survivors to your band with anywhere from 7-37 characters in your company, however only 7 are story related the rest are just generic copies of Azra 6 followers. You can assign all characters in your party with names other than the default ones, and generic defenders can be assign a color schema. There is a hard level cap of 60 for all characters, therefore you will not be able to max all characters abilities (higher difficulties you will have prioritize the best move set for your characters). This is game is design philosophy has the old school mentality when it comes to unlockables: new game plus that adds sidequests/challenge maps (like fighting waves upon waves of sheep), harder story maps, and journal entries, books to equip Azra, unique weapons and armor/ their upgrades. Game allows you to fine to how easy or hard you want the game to be like granting no exp upon failure, increase the speed of the game. The game is very well supported by the developer, in fact received an HD upgrade without making the user pay for it again. TL:DRhighlights   humorous characters  a TD game with an actual plot  persistent level ups  free HD version and soundtrack  new game plus

Posted: November 24, 2016
												An extremely user-friendly interface, charming graphics, a solid base gameplay (with lots of variations and different levels of challenge) and entertaining, even if not mindblowing, story and dialogue.The base game doesn't last very long, but that also means that it doesn't overstay its welcome and that each level has at least a little something that makes it unique and prevents the player from always using the same strategy. The fact that each level has two optional challenges and that there's a New Game+ mean that there are a lot of potential challenges for the players who want them.Most importantly, the user interface never hides any information. You always know exactly what your characters can do and what the enemies will do if you let them. If you lose in this game it's because you did something wrong or your characters weren't strong enough, not because of some obscure "gotcha" mechanic or random chance.My only problem with the game is the fact that interesting and important story content (a personal sidequest for each one of the major characters) is only available in New Game + mode. When you're replaying the game, you're probably fast-forwarding past the story so you're probably going to see these scenes in a vacuum. On the other hand when you're playing the first time, which is the only time you're actually paying attention to the story, the characters will feel underdeveloped because their development is hidden in their personal sidequests. I think the game would be better if all story content were available during your first "run", and the New Game+ mode was just about gameplay and challenge.That said, this is an interesting and charming little game that succeeds in fusing RPG progression and tower defense gameplay, and is more than worth the money.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												I'll confess that I haven't played the new HD update. Someday if I have time and feel like replaying this, I'll check it out. But the fact that I put so much time into this game BEFORE the snazzy update probably says something.I don't play much tower defense, so I can't really compare and contrast, but this was a thoroughly fun game that you can probably enjoy if you like RTSes or tactical RPGs. It's got a solid story, endearing characters, and fun writing that doesn't take itself especially seriously. The game pretty much always feels balanced and makes good use of the mechanics it's established, at least over the course of the main story.Some of the end-game challenges can be very frustrating. At one point I decided I wanted to try to 100% this game, but I could never get those last few achievements no matter how hard I tried. I was putting so much time into the game that I got tired of the soundtrack and turned off the music to play my own tunes. (My friends always thought some of the sounds from this game sounded like I was repeatedly booting up a PS1.) Don't be afraid to look up guides if you're trying that stuff yourself.Still, all that is just post-game content that is by no means necessary to enjoy the experience. You can power through the main story on the lower difficulties in not too much time. The extra content will keep you busy if you want it, though. This game is a bit of an underdog that I highly recommend. Also, absolutely deserving of the Best Use of a Farm Animal award for the Super Sheep secret boss. Oh, and the main character is a librarian, which I am too!

Posted: July 14, 2013
												I'm not strongly into tower defense (TD) games, but this game does away with some of the downsides of tower defense games which bother me. Your towers are characters you gain as you progress in the story, or purchase at various points. Your team protects your summoner, and both the characters and summoner, gain XP after each battle (win or lose, although that can be adjusted). If the game becomes too hard, you can replay an earlier level for extra XP / scrap (the game's currency). However, replaying levels is not grindy-feeling, since each level can be played at three different difficulty levels, which is a different than just the same monsters with more HP (for example, sometimes there are additional spawn points and sometimes the monsters have additional bonuses). (And if you really don't like redoing levels for XP and scrap, you can increase the gain of each of them.)Unlike some TD games, there is no pathing manipulation: the squares the characters can be placed on are different than the creeps' travel squares. That doesn't mean that character placement is permanent: it is sometimes useful to remove and re-place characters (especially in boss levels or the bonus levels available during the second playthrough).Speaking of the second playthrough, that isn't just the same monsters, but more HP. Usually the second playthrough monsters have additional abilities, such as attacking your characters as they walk by, or become temporarily immune to non-area damage. The second playthrough also allows purchase or unlock of the best weaponry. Another nice touch is that switching between the first and second playthrough is just a matter of returning to the menu; your entire party and loot remains the same. (I worked a bit on the second playthrough, got stuck, went back to the first playthrough to do some of the harder difficulties of the levels, got stuck, went back to the second playthrough, et cetera.)Besides your party characters, the summoner has a few spells that unlock while progressing through the story and can be increased as the summoner's level increases. These spells can help out during tight spots in earlier levels, and are pretty much required for the hardest levels.Slak says to at least try the demo; pants are optional.

Posted: November 18, 2012
												Edit again: Okay, now I can change my review back to a recommended. While the rerelease had a really shaky start, the devs have been great about talking to people, filing bug reports, and a really quickly released series of patches that have put the game in a good state again. I'm glad that the game is stable again because it remains one of my favorites and most played in my entire Steam library.Edit: Three and a half years later, I'm having to edit my review on the HD rerelease of the game. Do no buy it in its current condition. It is an incredibly buggy mess. The game constantly crashes, graphical and UI glitches abound, certain equipped items will make maps literally unwinnable. How this version of the game was allowed to see the light of day is baffling. Wait until it's been patched a few times, which the devs ARE being very quick and responsive about.If you at all enjoy tower defense games, buy this. Now. It injects cocaine through your mouse and keyboard right into your body. It's so addictive it's ridiculous. The graphics are a bit basic and it doesn't have a huge epic storyline, but it's like one of those really good Flash games polished to a mirror sheen. A mirror you snort crack off of.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is one of those rare RPG / tower defense games that are actually really good. The story was pretty good. The gameplay was pretty balanced. It's only as difficult as you want it to be which is perfect. The graphics are... well, look at the screenshots. I completed the story, and I'm not bored with it yet. Which is good because the game unlocked an entirely new game mode which means many more hours of playtime. The game has a bunch of well placed humor which adds a lot to the game / story. The game was definitely worth what I paid for it, and I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a game like this.For the record, I played in Hero only mode which added some challenge while also making the micro-managing a lot easier. I found out that the default 300% scrap setting is way too high since I never spend any of it... except for the last stretch where the stores give you access to a lot of really expensive gear which pretty much consumed most of my scrap.I especially laughed when the game decided to reward me anyways for my stubborness.
